: ''[[L'Ã©toile du nord]] (note capitalization) is also an [[opera]]''. It is also the title of a [[short story]] by the French writer [[Georges Simenon]] and [[L'Ãtoile du Nord (Tunis)| a theatre in Tunis]]. '''''L'Ãtoile du Nord''''' is a [[French language|French]] phrase meaning "'''The Star of the North'''". It is the [[List of U.S. state mottos|motto]] of the [[U.S. state]] of [[Minnesota]].<ref>{{cite web | title = 2006 Minnesota Statute Â§ 1.135, subd. 3(f)(1) | publisher = State of Minnesota Revisor of Statutes | url = http://ros.leg.mn/bin/getpub.php?pubtype=STAT_CHAP_SEC&year=current&section=1.135&image.x=34&image.y=9 | accessdate = 2007-02-19 }}</ref> It was chosen by the state's first governor, [[Henry Hastings Sibley]], and was adopted in 1861, three years after admission of Minnesota to the union.<ref name = Motto>{{cite web|url=http://www.leg.state.mn.us/leg/Symbols.asp#motto|format=|title=Minnesota State Symbols: State Motto|accessdate=2007-02-19}}</ref> Because of this motto, one of Minnesota's nicknames is ''The North Star State''. The [[Minnesota North Stars]] chose the English translation for their name.
